courseDescription: Students examine the historical and philosophical foundations that have shaped the profession of occupational therapy, its domain, values, and theories, and the foundations of practice with individuals, groups, and populations. Students explore the value of occupation and the role of occupational therapy in promoting health and wellness.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of health and wellness promotion
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding the history and philosophy of occupational therapy
Strategic planning for health and wellness promotion

courseDescription: Students analyze the domains and dimensions of occupations, occupational performance skills and patterns, and the structures, functions, and processes of the body and body systems. Students conduct biomechanical assessments and identify essential performance for health and function.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analysis of body and body systems
Identification of essential performance for health and function
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of domains and dimensions of occupations
Analytical evaluation of occupational performance skills and patterns

courseDescription: Students analyze the domains and dimensions of occupations, occupational performance skills and patterns, and the structures, functions, and processes of the body and body systems. Students will examine the structures and function of the central, autonomic and peripheral nervous systems and apply neuroscience principles to clinical conditions that disrupt human engagement and performance.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of body structures and functions
Knowledge of central, autonomic and peripheral nervous systems
Application of neuroscience principles to clinical conditions
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical evaluation of occupational performance skills and patterns
Problem solving for human engagement and performance disruptions
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and structuring knowledge of body and body systems
Leadership in applying neuroscience principles to clinical conditions

courseDescription: Students analyze the domains and dimensions of occupations, occupational performance skills and patterns, and the structures, functions, and processes of the body and body systems. Students examine human development and occupational patterns across the lifespan and the cultures that enable individuals, groups and populations to optimally participate in occupations that promote health.
Technical and Digital Skills: Examination of body structures, functions, and processes
Understanding of human development and occupational patterns
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing occupational performance skills and patterns
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on occupational patterns across the lifespan

courseTitle: Occupation, Health and Wellness Across the Lifespan
courseDescription: Students examine human development, occupational patterns, and cultural influences across the lifespan that enable individuals, groups and populations to optimally participate in occupations that promote health. Students apply critical reasoning to consider the impact of disorders on participation and health.

courseTitle: Pediatric Habilitation and Rehabilitation: Theory and Practice
courseDescription: Students examine occupations and the evaluation and treatment of physical, developmental, psychosocial, and mental health disorders of children and youth. Students design evaluation and intervention plans for clients receiving services in hospital, developmental, and school settings.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing individual needs and developmental progress
Problem solving for diverse client needs

courseTitle: Professional Reasoning and the Occupational Therapy Process
courseDescription: Students utilize professional and clinical reasoning to apply the occupational therapy process in client care. Students analyze information that supports team collaboration, clinical decision making, effective client care, and service reporting.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of occupational therapy process in client care

courseDescription: Students integrate foundational concepts to promote professionalism, ethical reasoning, therapeutic use of self, and lifelong competent and interprofessional practice. Students examine professional identity and the role of professional relationships in occupational therapy practice.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Constructive communication in a professional setting

courseDescription: Immersed in a setting that serves the needs of children and youth, students develop a summary of a client’s occupational history and experiences, patterns of daily living, interests, values, needs, and relevant environments and contexts, and examine client-centered outcomes.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interpreting client's interests and relevant environments
Effective communication with children and youth
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing client’s occupational history and experiences
Assessing needs of children and youth
Evaluating the impact of relevant environments and contexts on client

courseTitle: Elements of Research I: Theories of Inquiry and Scholarly Literature
courseDescription: Students develop knowledge of the application of statistics for the healthcare professional. Students utilize descriptive statistics, normality, parametric and non-parametric hypothesis testing and simple linear regression to evaluate research and form clinical decisions.

courseTitle: Elements of Research II: Using Evidence to Inform Practice
courseDescription: Students apply knowledge of practice and research to design effective intervention to meet clients’ needs. Students design clinical questions related to diagnosis, prognosis, and intervention, and critically appraise the research literature on a topic of interest to the practice community.

courseTitle: Education and Learning in Healthcare and Academic Settings
courseDescription: Students explore teaching and learning theory, threshold concepts, and signature pedagogy in occupational therapy academic and fieldwork education. Activity analysis and learning strategies to promote health literacy, performance, engagement, and behavioral change are examined.
Technical and Digital Skills: Implementing signature pedagogy in occupational therapy
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in academic and fieldwork education

courseDescription: Students will examine approaches to professional development and strategic planning and examine their leadership competencies. They will discuss roles and responsibilities and develop a professional leadership and business plan.

courseTitle: Health Care Policy and Program Management
courseDescription: Factors, forces, and dynamics of the healthcare system and service delivery environment are examined, and students compare the interrelationships of health policy, healthcare, and practice. Students conduct an epidemiological analysis of a challenging healthcare issue.

Students examine the elements of developing and maintaining relationships, communicating with clients and members of the team, and resolving interpersonal challenges in the roles of practitioner, practice scholar, and leader/advocate.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem solving in a client-practitioner relationship
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizational skills in a therapeutic setting

courseDescription: Students conduct an occupation-based assessment of a client in a clinical or community-based setting that serves the needs of adults with disabilities. Students examine occupational performance and its impact on participation and health and wellness in individuals and groups.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and responding to client needs
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification of health and wellness needs
Developing individual and group intervention strategies
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project coordination in clinical or community-based settings

courseDescription: Students examine occupations and the evaluation and treatment of physical, psychosocial, and mental health disorders of adults. Students design evaluation and intervention plans for clients receiving services in acute and sub-acute care, inpatient and outpatient rehabilitation, and community-based settings.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of physical, psychosocial, and mental health disorders
Knowledge of acute and sub-acute care
Understanding of inpatient and outpatient rehabilitation
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Treatment planning for diverse health conditions
Analyzing rehabilitation needs in various settings
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing client care in multiple settings

courseTitle: Productive Aging and Rehabilitation: Theory and Practice
courseDescription: Students examine the aging process and the evaluation and treatment of physical, developmental, psychosocial, and mental health disorders of older adults. Students design evaluation and intervention plans for clients receiving services in home, community, and skilled nursing settings.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding physical, developmental, psychosocial, and mental health disorders
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting interventions to individual client circumstances
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating client care across home, community, and skilled nursing settings

courseTitle: Mental Health Promotion and Recovery: Theory and Practice
courseDescription: Students examine the influence of psychosocial factors on occupational performance and participation in individuals, groups, and populations. Use of self as a therapeutic agent and group process skills are emphasized.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Use of self as a therapeutic agent
Ability to communicate psychosocial factors and their impact on occupational performance
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification and implementation of strategies for mental health promotion and recovery

courseDescription: Students examine the role of technology in the occupational therapy process from evaluation to intervention planning and implementation. The regulation and ethics of technology use in therapy are considered and students explore the array of technological resources available for patient care.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of technology in occupational therapy
Exploration of technological resources for patient care
Evaluation and implementation of therapeutic technology
Understanding of technology regulation and ethics in therapy
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of the role of technology in occupational therapy
Planning and implementation of therapeutic interventions
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Regulation and ethics of technology use in therapy

courseDescription: Students apply professional reasoning and activity analysis to meet clients’ occupational needs. Students analyze, grade, modify, and adapt occupations and activities to support occupational performance and participation.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying ways to support occupational performance and participation
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and implementing occupational adaptation strategies

courseDescription: Students conduct evaluations and design a group-based intervention in a clinical or community-based setting that serves the needs of adults with disabilities. Students examine occupational performance and its impact on participation and health and wellness in individuals and groups.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Working effectively in a community-based setting
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing impact on individual and group health and wellness
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading in a clinical or community-based setting

courseTitle: Elements of Research III: Critical Analysis of Occupational Therapy Practice
courseDescription: Students analyze the external and internal criticisms of the profession and examine the evidence addressing practice. Students examine the body of evidence addressing an intervention of interest and complete a systematic review of the evidence.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing external and internal criticisms of a profession
Evaluating the validity of a body of evidence
Identifying effective interventions based on evidence
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing a body of research for review

courseTitle: Elements of Research IV: Scholarship of Practice Approaches and Design
courseDescription: Students explore research approaches and design and participate in grant writing and a mentored research project with a faculty member that links theory and practice, facilitates understanding of complex real-world issues, and facilitates knowledge translation.

In this twelve-week full-time course, students are provided supervised field experiences applying the occupational therapy process with individuals, groups and/or populations with occupational performance and participation needs.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of occupational performance and participation needs
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with individuals and groups
Adapting communication style to different populations
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Tailoring therapy processes for individual needs
Evaluating effectiveness of occupational therapy interventions
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading therapy sessions for individuals and groups

courseDescription: In this twelve-week full-time course, students are provided supervised field experiences applying the occupational therapy process with individuals, groups and/or populations with occupational performance and participation needs.

Students examine the role of occupation in health promotion, health education, and prevention of illness. Key concepts of population health, social determinates of health, health promotion, and health behavior will be applied to develop community and population-based approaches.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of health-related software and applications
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and executing health promotion campaigns

courseDescription: Students examine their knowledge, skills and professional competencies and establish a resume and professional development plan. Students examine the value of supervision and mentorship relationships.

Students examine the formation of their identity as an occupation-based practice scholar and ethical leader and explore challenges in service delivery systems of significance to occupational therapy’s value and role in health and wellness promotion.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying challenges in service delivery systems
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Identity formation as a practice scholar

courseDescription: Students examine innovative approaches to service delivery and discuss their formative capstone experience and their potential role as a practitioner, practice scholar, and leader/advocate in health management and promotion.

Students examine their capacity for leadership and advocacy for the role of occupation in achieving health and wellbeing of individuals, groups, and populations. Students reflect on their own plans for leadership and advocacy in their upcoming capstone project.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Examination and analysis of leadership capacity
Evaluation of health and wellbeing strategies

courseDescription: The doctoral capstone project is a 14-week full-time experiential course designed to develop students’ skills role related focus areas. Students implement an individually mentored, increasingly self-directed capstone project as the culminating learning activity of the doctoral program.

The synthesis of knowledge gained throughout the didactic curriculum, service-learning and field experiences, and in-depth scholarly capstone experience and project is demonstrated through the completion and presentation of a scholarly product.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of digital tools for scholarly work
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration in service-learning and field experiences
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in service-learning and field experiences
Organizing and executing a scholarly project
